moves.1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bc4 Bc5: The "Quiet Game" will soon turn not so quiet.
moves.4. c3 Nf6 5. O-O: 5 P-Q4 is the usual --and good -- move. This move allows Winawer to make a quick tactical strike that leaves him with a dominating Pawn position.
moves.5... Nxe4 6. Bd5 Nxf2: The risky but potentially devastating tactical finesse is underway.
moves.7. Rxf2 Bxf2+: This gives Winawer two more Pawns than Albin. If Winawer can quickly mobilize his Pawns, Albin will be swept off the board. Albin must counter by quickly developing his Q-side.
moves.9. Qb3 O-O: Winawer secures his own King before engaging in attacking maneuvers. Albin *must* now focus on developing his Q-side pieces.
moves.10. Be4 d5: This Pawn advances with tempo, as White is forced to move his wandering Bishop yet again.
moves.11. Bc2 e4: Now Winawer gains another tempo, as Albin must move his Knight. Albin's Q-side is still a hopeless mess.
moves.12. Ne1 Ng6: Preparing for ...P-KB4-B5 and also opening the diagonal for ...Q-R5 ch.
moves.13. c4 d4: 14 BxP? Q-R5 ch! wins the B.
moves.14. Qg3 f5: The Pawns are sweeping forward in an inexorable Black wave, pushing aside everything in their path.
moves.15. Kg1 c5: Yet another Pawn advances. Albin can do nothing to stop the invasion.
moves.17. Qf2 e3: Gaining another tempo by again attacking the Q.
moves.18. Qf3 Qh4: Preparing to mount the final assault on the forlorn White King. With the Q-side pieces as useful as a cast-iron life jacket, Albin can mount no adequate defense.
moves.19. Qd5+ Kh8: Dodging away from the spite check.
moves.22. Qg5 Bh3: Albin resigns. Black simply has too many threats.
